image.altText: A truck drives out of the entrance of the Darwin Port on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: In a statement, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet says that there is "a robust regulatory system in place to manage risks to critical infrastructure" and that it "was not necessary to vary or cancel the lease".

title.children: Federal government will not cancel Chinese company's Port of Darwin lease

image.altText: Trucks lined up in Egypt.

items.synopsis: The United Nations humanitarian office says it is in "deep and advanced negotiations with all relevant sides" to open a humanitarian corridor into Gaza "as quickly as possible". Follow live.

title.children: UN says it is in 'deep' negotiations to open corridor to Gaza as stockpiles grow at Rafah crossing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are signs some Palestinians who moved south in response to the Israeli order to evacuate are returning to their homes, because air strikes are taking place in the south too, the UN human rights office says. “We remain very concerned that Israeli Forces’ heavy strikes are continuing across Gaza, including in the south,” spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani told reporters. “The strikes, coupled with extremely difficult living conditions in the south, appear to have pushed some to return to the north, despite the continuing heavy bombing there.” About one week ago Israel's miliary ordered about 1.1 civilians in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south, prompting the UN to warn of "devastating humanitarian consequences". Ms Shamdasani said the rights office had since heard accounts about people wanting to migrate back north, including from one unidentified Palestinian who said: “I might as well die in my own house.” Associated Press
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: After being told to flee to the south, the UN says some Palestinians are returning home

children.content: There are signs some Palestinians who moved south in response to the Israeli order to evacuate are returning to their homes, because air strikes are taking place in the south too, the UN human rights office says.
Northern Gazans were told to evacuate and travel south last week.
(AP: Hatem Moussa)
“We remain very concerned that Israeli Forces’ heavy strikes are continuing across Gaza, including in the south,” spokesperson Ravina Shamdasani told reporters.
“The strikes, coupled with extremely difficult living conditions in the south, appear to have pushed some to return to the north, despite the continuing heavy bombing there.”
About one week ago Israel's miliary ordered about 1.1 civilians in northern Gaza to evacuate to the south, prompting the UN to warn of "devastating humanitarian consequences".
Ms Shamdasani said the rights office had since heard accounts about people wanting to migrate back north, including from one unidentified Palestinian who said: “I might as well die in my own house.”
Associated Press

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The UN humanitarian office says it is in "deep and advanced negotiations with all relevant sides" to open a humanitarian corridor into Gaza "as quickly as possible". "We are encouraged by reports that the sides are nearing an agreement on the modalities, and that a first aid delivery to Gaza is due to start in the next day or so," the UN office says. Humanitarian organisations have been stockpiling supplies in northern Egypt ahead of the planned opening of the Rafah crossing — the only road into Gaza not controlled by Israel. Egypt previously said it never formally closed the crossing but that "repeated bombings" by Israel on the Gaza side of the crossing had put it out of operation. The crossing was expected to open today and allow 20 trucks to deliver aid into the Palestinian enclave. Reuters/AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza aid to be delivered 'in the next day or so,' UN says

children.content: The UN humanitarian office says it is in "deep and advanced negotiations with all relevant sides" to open a humanitarian corridor into Gaza "as quickly as possible".
"We are encouraged by reports that the sides are nearing an agreement on the modalities, and that a first aid delivery to Gaza is due to start in the next day or so," the UN office says.
Trucks carrying humanitarian aid for Gaza civilians have been waiting for the Rafah crossing to re-open.
(Reuters)
Humanitarian organisations have been stockpiling supplies in northern Egypt ahead of the planned opening of the Rafah crossing — the only road into Gaza not controlled by Israel.
Egypt previously said it never formally closed the crossing but that "repeated bombings" by Israel on the Gaza side of the crossing had put it out of operation.
The crossing was expected to open today and allow 20 trucks to deliver aid into the Palestinian enclave.
Reuters/AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel plans to evacuate residents from the town of Kiryat Shmona near its border with Lebanon, the Defense Ministry has announced. Residents of the town near the border will be moved to state-subsidised guesthouses, the ministry said. Kiryat Shmona is in Israel's north and just a few kilometres from the border, across which Israeli troops and militants in Lebanon have been exchanging fire. In a separate announcement posted on social media, the Israeli Air Force said overnight it had "eliminated a terrorist" in Lebanese territory and destroyed a number of military targets belonging to Hezbollah.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel announces plans to evacuate residents of border town near Lebanon

children.content: Israel plans to evacuate residents from the town of Kiryat Shmona near its border with Lebanon, the Defense Ministry has announced.
Residents of the town near the border will be moved to state-subsidised guesthouses, the ministry said.
Kiryat Shmona is in Israel's north and just a few kilometres from the border, across which Israeli troops and militants in Lebanon have been exchanging fire.

In a separate announcement posted on social media, the Israeli Air Force said overnight it had "eliminated a terrorist" in Lebanese territory and destroyed a number of military targets belonging to Hezbollah.
